message: Hey! Good timing. I was super busy all week. I’m definitely around this weekend! 716-346-0232
Hey! No problem. I’m sorry for the delay in my response. I’m in New York until Wednesday. I’d love to hang out Thursday - on. Are you going to be around next weekend?
Hey I’m so sorry for not responding. I’m so terrible with using tinder. I’m flying home from DC today but if you’re still in buffalo. I’d love to hang out
Hey, are you still using tinder? how have you been?

Hey! I’m sorry for inundating you messages. I enjoyed the brief exchange we shared and would like to continue it, so please don’t feel compelled to write an essay back, unless of course you’d like to. How are you doing?

Thanks for your kind words about Call Congress. I’ve worked on a couple other smaller politically motivated projects as well. I won’t bore you with them here but perhaps we could talk about them in person (if you’d like). 
You’re passionate, motivated, driven, kind hearted, and gorgeous. I am incredibly surprised that you’re on tinder and feel very lucky to have matched with you. If you don’t mind my asking, why are you here? What are you looking for / Are you looking for more than laughs? If so, I’d love to treat you to coffee, dinner, or even a mini-adventure.

Costa Rica is gorgeous. Columbia is as well. I’ve never been to Brazil but I’d love to go. I hope you’re able to travel more too. Funny enough, I spent part of today planning a trip to the Atacama desert and La Serena in Chile for the July 2nd, 2019 eclipse with some of my friends (airbnb’s fill up very quickly).

I completely agree about running for office and I think a lot of other wealthy, intelligent, and influential people agree with you as well. I’m interested to hear your thoughts on how you/we can inspire, motivate, and involve more people from your/our respective positions. I tend to favor quantity of people over quality of involvement, but that may be because so far, I haven’t truly connected or inspired anyone. I would love to read your blog when you decide to start it.

I was a huge bernie supporter as well. In 2016 I lived in Palo Alto and was registered to vote there. I was enraged when the AP announced (conspired with) Hillary had secured enough delegates for the nomination one day before the California primary. Bernie excited my non-politically active friends as well, almost as much as Trump has excited them since his election (this is the only thing I feel grateful to Trump for). My single greatest political hope is that the democratic party will be able to produce a candidate as great as Bernie for 2020.
Hi Krystina! Did you march today?
I’ve never been to South America surprisingly. I’ve heard Costa Rica is gorgeous. I’d love to go to Brazil and Columbia as well.

5-10 years? I’d love to still work for a non for profit with a cause I’m passionate about. I’d love to start a blog about politics, change and millennials. I’m very passionate about secular humanism and science so maybe a little bit of that in there as well. It might sound naive but I think I can be more useful at a grassroots level.

No, I don’t think I’d ever run for office. This might sound cynical but the way our system is now, I think I can get much more done with what I’m currently doing. I want to get more millennials like myself interested in politics and for them to realize it’s not a spectator sport. I love getting people involved.

So sorry for the delay in response! It’s been a crazy day. Hahah I loved that quip about her director of engineering. The Call Congress project is amazing! So many people don’t know who their reps are and it’s so local politics is so crucial. I love it! I was actually a huge Bernie support and partially blamed the DNC after trump was elected. Of course, I voted for Hilary and I don’t loathe her but I wasn’t her biggest fan. She would’ve been perfectly fine for the job. Bernie actually got friends of mine who aren’t politically active to get excited. To me, he was the change a lot of people were craving especially with big interests and Wall Street.

Sorry for the long rambling comments. Your job sounds really cool(!) and you’re working for such an incredible cause. I wish that there were less people that irrationally hated planned parenthood. Have you ever considered a career as a public servant? What do you see yourself doing 5/10 years from now?

A few years ago I worked on a project called Call Congress, where I’d automatically connect you with all of your representatives from your area code if you dialed a toll-free number. Last year one of my friends built a great site called track-trump.com that covered trump’s first 100 days and another friend created an online voter registration site called voteplz. I’ve been so enraged by politics and I really want to do more. The head of engineering at the NGO I work with was Hillary Clinton’s Director of Engineering (he doesn’t like to talk about email servers). I’ve promised myself that I’ll volunteer during the next election cycle, probably with him.
our massively increased defense budget.*

Trump … I agree that he’s unlikely to resign. I don’t think he’ll be in office past January of 2019. There are so many charges that Trump could face. At the very least I think he will be charged with Obstruction of Justice and when impeached (if McConnell allows impeachment hearings to be scheduled) there won’t be enough votes to remove him from office. I also think Mueller/Goldstein will provide ample evidence of money laundering soon, which will be much more likely to result in a successful impeachment.  Trump could also be prosecuted by the NY AG for money laundering and Martin act violations, which may or may not create a constitutional crisis. It would be interesting to see if Trump could be charged while President. While I’d love to see Trump go, a Pence Ryan presidency would be truly horrifying to me. Separately, I’m very worried about what’s going to happen with John Bolton (last month, he argued for a pre-emptive strike on NK, now he is the National Security Advisor) and ou...

I’ve been to nearly all of the coffee producing regions except in El Salvador. Costa Rica is probably my favorite country in Central America. I always try to spend a few days surfing in Nosara when I go. Have you traveled around Central America?

Wow that’s awesome! Where in Central America? I’ll definitely read up on it. Ah Trump. I’m still not convinced he will be kicked out office at all. Unlike Nixon, Trump will never resign no matter how much heat is on him. Proving Trump committed a crime isn’t as easy as it looks. So, I’m hopeful but not that optimistic. I’m an organizer for Planned Parenthood of Central and WNY. I organize volunteers, engage with local politicians, lobby, table events ect.

I don’t meet many people like yourself either(!). I’m incredibly impressed that you’ve traveled to Cuba. I’ve heard incredible things about it, a close French-Cuban friend grew up there and talks as if it’s the most amazing place in the world. I’d love to go. 
I spend ~ 10% of my time with a startup NGO called Enveritas that does sustainability verification in the coffee sector. They operate in ~30 countries but I’ve only worked in Central America and East Africa. The rest of my time goes to a company I work remotely for. You can read more about it/me at my website (https://mldangelo.com) if you’d like, but please be gentle, as it was designed to impress engineers and not for this audience. 
Thank you for the tip about the valley of the kings. I have a friend from grad school based in Cairo and I’ll probably beg him to show me around. How much longer do you think Trump will remain in office for? What do you do for planned parenthood?

Oh wow. I don’t meet many people like yourself here in Buffalo. If I might ask, which NGO do you work with? If you add Egypt to your trip, I’ve heard to avoid the pyramids at Giza and instead go to the valley of the kings. A few months ago I spent two weeks in Cuba and it was unexpectedly mind blowing. I’d love to go back especially because it’s such a quick flight.
Out of all of the places you’ve been, where would you most like to go back to?

Nepal is very high on my list, but I’m also open to Southeast Asia. Egypt is also in my top 10. I make ~ 4 trips per year to East Africa with an NGO I work with. Im hoping to add a trip to Egypt/Jordan at the end of an upcoming trip.
Hi there! That’s awesome! It’s between Egypt or Thailand. I’m pretty torn. What about yourself?
Hey Krystina! I am also a political junkie and I live to travel. Where do you most want to go next?
